result.title: Objective
result.description: Biodiversity management is integrated into forestry practices on community lands through market-based instruments

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Increase in Community Forestry Enterprises (CFEs) dedicating resources to biodiversity conservation and implementing specific measures related to biodiversity, measured as
# of ha of biodiversity set-asides within certified CFEs
% of certified CFEs with High Conservation Value Forest (HCVF) assessments undertaken
% of certified CFEs applying specific measures related to biodiversity to areas under production management

baseline.comment:
144,829 ha of biodiversity set-asides in certified CFEs
40% of certified CFEs with HCVF assessments completed
0 CFEs applying the HCVF toolkit, ERA tool or BPM

target.comment:
244,829 ha of BD set-asides
100% of certified CFEs with HCVF assessments completed
At least 40 certified CFEs applying tools

actual.comment:
a) Considering that some pieces of land reported during earlier periods have been subject to recertification processes, which has entailed an adjustment to areas with high conservation values in some cases, an exercise was undertaken to verify and update information on areas reported in the available support documents. Additionally, the information was confirmed by personnel of RA-Cert. During this exercise, it was identified that some pieces of land were reported at different times, thereby duplicating information. Therefore, adjustments were made.
In this regard, of the 37 baseline CFEs, 34 have completed their studies to identify areas with high conservation values, with a total area of 227,381.13 hectares (ha). Of these 34 CFEs, two successfully completed their study in this period: Comunidad Santiago Textitlán (1,309 ha) and the Foresters' Union of Zapotecas-Chinantecas de la Sierra de Juárez de R.I.(26,293.62 ha), both in Oaxaca.
Of the pieces of land set out on the baseline, 28 are certified. In this regard, the HCV area on certified pieces of land is 196,874,477 ha
In addition to the baseline, the studies concluded amount to 80. Through these, the area identified with high conservation values is 313,396 ha; of the 80 pieces of land, 34 are certified and have an HVC area of 59,501.09 ha. Of the 72 pieces of land, 39 concluded their studies in this period with an area of 91,591 ha. Of these, 11 are certified and have a total HCV area of 20,427.24 ha.
Of the 39 additional pieces of land that completed their study in this period, 21 are in the Northern Region with 50,297 ha; six are in the Central Region with 7,784.14 ha; nine are in the East Central Region with an area of 1,812.78 ha; two pieces of land are in the Southern Region with 6,697.26; and one is in the Southeastern Region with 1 of 25,000 ha.
In total, there is a cumulative area of 540,777 ha identified in the studies with high conservation value characteristics, which means that 220% of the planned goal was met.
b) 91% of baseline CFEs have completed their HCV study (34 CFEs). Of these, two CFEs concluded their HCV study in 2014-2015.
In addition to the baseline, 80 studies have been concluded, 34 of which were concluded during the 2014-2015 period.
On a cumulative basis, in the project's areas of focus, there are 114 studies to identify high conservation value areas, a number above the scheduled goal.
c) 114 CFEs have completed their studies to identify high conservation value areas, which have been incorporated into their Forest Management Plans (FMPs).
Additionally, 592 pieces of land are recorded that incorporate biodiversity criteria into their Forest Management Programs (FMPs) based on the "Manual of Best Biodiversity Conservation Practices" that the project produced in 2013, which has had an impact on an area of around 1.2 million ha. Additionally, with the CONAFOR's support, eight consultancies are in process of being hired to advise producers on incorporating biodiversity criteria into their FMPs on 720 pieces of land in the states of Chihuahua, Durango, Jalisco, Michoacán, Puebla Oaxaca, Guerrero, Campeche, and Quintana Roo, which amount to 1.1 million ha.
On the other hand, the project designed a base structure to conduct Regional Biodiversity Studies (RBSs) Currently, there are 12 RBSs in Chihuahua and Durango in their final stage of being carried out. They consider biodiversity conservation practices for sites, stands, and landscapes as well as the identification of high conservation value attributes in an area of 8 million ha.
Likewise, 131 Community Forest Enterprises (CFEs) were trained to prepare their Biological Monitoring and Habitat Quality Programs; ; these tools allow them to obtain or maintain certification and provide information on the impact of productive activity on the piece of land's biodiversity.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Strengthened institutional capacity to support biodiversity conservation through certified community forestry

baseline.comment: Low national-scale capacity to assist biodiversity mgmt in certified production forest

target.comment:
3 BD mgmt and monitoring tools adapted and in application
-300 staff trained in certification and BD mgmt extension.

actual.comment:
An element that has contributed to the functioning of the project and achievement of its goals is the generation of knowledge products. These tools serve to support producers and technical service providers in implementing practices that contribute to biodiversity conservation. Additionally, they are useful to public servants (mainly of the CONAFOR and the SEMARNAT) for giving opinions on forest management projects and support resources.
In this regard, the following four new knowledge products have also been developed during this period:
1. Road Manual: "Techniques to Control el Sediment on Secondary Forest Roads".
2. Forest Management: Reserva Forestal Multifuncional "El Manantial" S.C. Concepts, Conduct, and Actions"
3. Forest Habitat Characterization and Classification Guide
4. General guidelines to incorporate biodiversity conservation into FMPs for utilization of timber forest resources.
The documents along with the Manual produced in 2013 have been published for consultation on the CONAFOR page (http://www.conafor.gob.mx/web/temas-forestales/biodiversidad/). Five new knowledge products have been created, representing 166% of the planned goal.
The HCV Identification Guide reported in the previous period is a document that considers a broad conceptual framework to identify High Conservation Values, a process which needs to be more operational.
Additionally, other knowledge products are being developed, which are expected to be completed no later than June 2016
b) A crucial element in implementing actions promoted by the project has been capacity building among different forestry sector stakeholders. In this regard, the reporting period has been the one with the greatest number of training events and persons trained. From June 2014 to July 2015, 104 training events took place, which 1,782 people attended. Of these people, 16% are technical personnel from the CONAFOR, 5% from the SEMARNAT, 1% from the PROFEPA, 1.5% from the CONABIO, 0.5% from the CONANP, 46% are Technical Service Providers, 6% are from State Governments, 14% are academics, and 9% are from NGOs. To date, 1,289 forest producers or CFE members have been trained.
Of the people trained, 24% now have knowledge of technical aspects and practices related to biodiversity conservation, 26% have strengthened their forest management capacities, 8% now have the technical capacities and knowledge to develop a biological monitoring system, 1% have the technical capacities and knowledge to develop an HCV study, 16% have knowledge of the country's certification tools, and 24% have received specialized consulting on the issue of competitiveness and markets.
We highlight the 491 women who attended training events during this period and who represent 16% of the total persons who attended.
Cumulatively, 194 training events on the different mentioned topics have been recorded. In these, 3,620 people from institutions, NGOs, TFSPs, and academics have participated, representing progress of 1,206% with respect to the planned goal. Additionally, 1,739 CFE members have participated.
In the Perception Study and Capacity Assessment commissioned by the project, a section was dedicated precisely to assessing to what extent training actions have helped to strengthen the capacities of the main stakeholders on issues promoted by the project.For purposes of comparison, groups of people under project intervention and not under project intervention were defined. Specifically for TFSPs, a set of questions of high technical difficulty was designed; the questions were validated with experts.
In this regard, the average score or percentage of correct answers given by the TFSPs under project intervention was 82%; meanwhile, the TFSPs not under project intervention obtained a score of 65%, which shows a notable difference of 17% between both groups.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3. Increase in competitiveness of CFEs enabling greater investments in BD conservation, measured through
Increase in CFE revenues
Increased investment in BD measures

baseline.comment:
Baseline:
CFE JuanacatlÃ¡n, Jal. $101,459.85
CFE San Pedro Jacuaro, Mich. $633,217.56
CFE San Rafael Ixtapaluca, Pue. $33,120.07
CFE Santo Domingo CoatlÃ¡n, Oax. $662,044.89
CFE Bajos del Balsamar, Gro $540,792.09
CFE San Pablo, Dgo. $2,295,351.00
CFE Yoquivo, Chih. $1,463,342.42
CFE Ãlvaro ObregÃ³n $1,040,000.00
CFE Petcacab $804,306.57
114,547.45 USD investment in BD

target.comment:
30% ave. increase in revenues
25% ave. increased investment in BD

actual.comment:
In June 2015, the third remeasurement of annual revenue (in USD) of the relevant CFEs determined through intensive monitoring was made (the second remeasurement after the baseline adjustment in the 2012-2013), resulting in the following values;
CFE Juanacatlán, Jal.: 250,508 USD
CFE San Pedro Jacuaro, Mich.: $592,126 USD
CFE San Rafael Ixtapaluca, Pue.: $90,146 USD
CFE Santo Domingo Coatlán, Oax.: $677,336 USD
CFE Bajos del Balsamar, Gro.: $139,567 USD
CFE San Pablo, Dgo.: $3,583,573 USD
CFE Ejido Yoquivo, Chi.: $1,891,202 USD
CFE Ejido Álvaro Obregón, Campeche: $25,157 USD
CFE Petcacab, Q. Roo.: $560,783 USD
At the regional level, by converting 2012 values (which are those of the project baseline) to current ones, the average is as follows:
Central Region: $289,861 USD, which represents a 97% increase in annual revenue with respect to the baseline.
Southern Region: $380,779 USD, 38% lower annual revenue with respect to the baseline due to a decreased utilization volume authorized by the SEMARNAT for the ejido of Bajos de Balsamar
Northern Region: $2,551,927 USD, 38% more annual revenue with respect to the baseline.
Southeast Region: $273,121 USD, 65% less with respect to the baseline, which is due to the persistence of the low sawmill operation in Álvaro Obregón and they are only dedicated to contract manufacturing of roundwood in small volumes.
According to the foregoing, there has been an average revenue increase of 18% with respect to the baseline. However, the South and Southeast regions had negative values. Recorded negative values are largely due to the decrease in volumes authorized by the SEMARNAT. It is important to mention that results during this period are are somewhat minimized when converted to US dollars because of the downward fluctuation of the peso, as well as to reiterate that revenues are largely determined by volumes authorized by the SEMARNAT.
To try to reverse the negative numbers in the Southern and Southeastern Regions, the implementation of different strategies that will be based on the following areas is sought:
Identifying specific market niches
Utilizing recycled resources
Region-level market studies for tropical wood products
On the other hand, the Mid-Term Review and the Project Board determined that monitoring only one CFE per state does not allow for the objective observation of project impact on competitiveness indicators of CFEs.
In this regard, in June 2015, the revenues of 35 CFEs in the project areas of focus was monitored. Average revenues by region are shown below:
Northern Region (7 CFEs): $3,944,411 USD
Central Region (7 CFEs): $417,204 USD
East Central Region (7 CFEs): $236,914 USD
Southern Region (8 CFEs): $434,787 USD
Southeastern Region (6 CFEs): 283,371 USD
The average revenue for the 35 monitored CFEs is $1,067,663 USD per year.
In 2016, the revenue of these same enterprises will be monitored again determine the amount of change with respect to the current period.
In relation to investment in biodiversity, the resources directly invested by the enterprises as well as the support resources received by the CONAFOR were considered and are related to actions aimed at conserving biodiversity.
The following values are the results for the 9 CFEs monitored since 2013:
Ejido Juanacatlán, Jal. $61,705 USD
Ejido San Pedro Jacuaro, Mich. $33,670 USD
Ejido San Rafael Ixtapalucan, Pue. $115,125 USD
Ejido Yoquivo, Chih. $224,080 USD
Ejido San Pablo, Dgo. $188,154 USD
Ejido Santo Domingo Coatlán, Oax. $84,226 USD
Ejido Bajos de Balsamar, Gro. $177,027 USD
Ejido Petcacab, Q Roo. $69,322 USD
Ejido Álvaro Obregón, Camp. $44,374 USD
Investment in biodiversity by the CFEs reached the highest values in this period, totaling around $1 million USD.
This represents 465% more than what was invested during the 2012-2013 period and almost eight times more than the level of investment recorded on the baseline ($114,547 USD).

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Technical assistance for community forest certification is institutionalized within national programs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Increase in technical and operational capacity within CONAFOR programs and among other groups to promote and apply sustainable forest management and biodiversity conservation processes

baseline.comment: No capacity support program for certification expansion or biodiversity conservation

target.comment:
Training program builds capacity among
100 CONAFOR staff
10 Forestry Technical Service Provider companies
and includes social, cultural and gender equity criteria

actual.comment:
The capacity building program of the Project is successful and has exceeded the goals set on the matter. The technical capacities of CONAFOR personnel, forestry service providers, and institutions on the environment, certification issues, biodiversity and forest management, forest monitoring, and HCVs were strengthened, and the issue of competitiveness and markets was also included, which is the largest area of opportunity identified in the Mid-Term Review.
During this period, 1,782 people from the institutions were trained in the aforementioned issues, broken down as follows: 294 people of the CONAFOR, 818 forestry service providers, and 670 people from other institutions relating to the environment.
Of the total people trained from institutions, 16% are CONAFOR personnel, 5% are of the SEMARNAT, 1.5% of the CONABIO, 1% of the PROFEPA, 0.5% of the CONANP, 46% are technical forestry service providers, 6% are from state governments, 14% are academics, and 9% are from NGOs.
During the lifespan of the project, 3,620 people from institutions have been trained in the subjects in question, of which 1,790 (53%) were TFSPs and 1,830 (47%) belong to federal agencies and NGOs. With this, the goal for "trained institutional personnel" has been surpassed.
With regard to training TFSP offices, there 138 offices on record that received this support, which signifies progress of more than 1,000% in relation to the planned goal. The breakdown of trained offices by region is described below:
Northern Region: 50 offices
Central Region: 14 offices
East Central Region: 21 offices
Southern Region: 22 offices
Southeastern Region: 31 offices
Cumulatively, in the project's lifespan so far, 162 TFSP offices (unduplicated) are on record as trained in the topics promoted by the project. This TSFP training strategy has had excellent results, as the profession has become an "arm" of the project that supports the dissemination and implementation of good biodiversity conservation practices and other matters.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Increased priority given to biodiversity goals in national production forest policies and programs

baseline.comment:
- Govâ€™t target to expand certification by 1 million ha nationwide
- CONAFOR evaluations of proposals for funding do not prioritize BD values and aims
- $260,000/yr invested specifically in BD through CONAFOR production forestry programs

target.comment:
- National strategy for certification expansion prioritizing BD-rich forests
- BD criteria integrated in CONAFOR evaluation of external proposals
- 50% increase in BD-specific investment by CONAFOR production forestry programs

actual.comment:
a) As reported in the previous period, forest certification and biodiversity conservation are priorities established in the National Forestry Program. One indicator of the importance of forest certification to the Mexican government is the national goal set in the PRONAFOR to "triple certified area by 2018," which is leading to a substantial increase in institutional investment intended to support forest certification.
The Mexican Standard NMX-AA-143-SCFI-2008 for certification of sustainable forest management has been strengthened with project inputs by making the criteria related to biodiversity conservation mandatory, as well as identifying high conservation value attributes, connectivity of habitats, and conservation of vertical and horizontal structures essential for biodiversity conservation.
The project also has participated in incorporating and strengthening the Mexican Forest Certification Council. A consultancy was hired to develop the Internal Rules of Operation and support said Council's formalization process before a notary public.
Through a consultant hired by the project, the Manual establishing the guidelines for Preventive Technical Audits was amended, strategic changes were made for its concurrence with the Mexican Standard on certification of sustainable forest management, along with changes to the National Forestry Certification System.Recently, the process to update the FSC International Certification Standard began. The project is participating in the review of 3 of its criteria, which will promote the incorporation of biodiversity conservation and a gender approach.
Also, in response to one of the main recommendations of the Mid-Term Review on promoting the drafting of a chain of custody standard, the project has participated in drafting and reviewing the assessment procedure for chain of custody forestry processes developed by the Asociación de Normalización y certificación A.C (ANCE).
b)The project contributed to amendments to the PRONAFOR Rules of Operation for 2013, 2014, and 2015 in collaboration with the Offices of Forest Development, Community Forest Development, and Supply Chain Integration, thereby providing technical inputs to the National Sustainable Forest Management Strategy for Increasing Production and Productivity.
Moreover, the Project financed the implementation of eight regional courses on regulation, management, and forest health coordinated by the Secretariat of Environment and Natural Resources, which were attended by 1,700 people from the SEMARNAT, PROFEPA, CONAFOR, CONANP, TFSPs, academics, forest producers, and others.It is worth mentioning that, through these courses, it was possible to hasten acceptance of biodiversity conservation among public servants and other stakeholders mentioned above.
c)While the support concept of "Carrying out Specialized Technical Studies to Establish Conservation Areas Rich in Biodiversity" is not present in the 2015 Rules of Operation, support resources to prepare studies for biodiversity conservation (an HCVA Study and Regional Biodiversity Studies) are granted through the following supports: "Certification" and "Regional Studies to Support Sustainable Forest Management."
During this cycle, the CONAFOR invested $141,799 USD in the concept of "international certification" meant for preparing HCV studies and $454,227 to develop 13 Regional Biodiversity Studies through the concept of "Regional Studies to Support Sustainable Forest Management," which cumulatively amounts to $596,026 for the period, which signifies more than 229% relative to the average annual investment recorded on the baseline ($260,000 USD).
Cumulatively, in the project's lifespan so far, the CONAFOR has directly invested $3,981,617 USD in support resources for biodiversity conservation in production forests.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Increase in federal and state demand for certified wood products from CFEs, resulting in sales contracts

baseline.comment:
- Federal policy requiring sourcing of certified material
- 1 state-level policy
- 0 contracts executed as a result of clarified sourcing information and new policies

target.comment:
- Federal policy prioritizing Mexican CFE certified material
- 5 new state policies
- 15 new contracts executed

actual.comment:
One of the project's main areas of opportunity is the development of national government demand for certified timber. It is a complex issue that requires the involvement of several federal agencies (SHCP, SEMARNAT, SEP, etc.). However, the project has made progress in generating information and projects that can have an impact on consolidating the demand for certified forest products by public institutions.
-Study of the sawn timber market
In December 2014, the "Study of the Sawn Timber Market in Mexico" was finalized. It includes an analysis of market conditions and sawn timber from tropical species in Mexico and the demand for certified timber products by the federal government, state governments, and the private sector.
-National Wood Energy Program
As part of the project's strategies to develop and diversify the demand for products derived from sustainable forest management, the implementation of projects to generate electricity from forest biomass has been identified as a viable option. In this regard, the project financed the implementation of the National Wood Energy Program (PRONADEN), from which a first draft was already generated, which underwent validation before a group of experts and the comments received are in process of being addressed.Apart from containing the strategies to be followed by the project and the CONAFOR on power generation through forest biomass,
-Green Procurement Decree.
Through the Forest Development Office and in collaboration with the project, the CONAFOR is reviewing the "Decree whereby Various Measures for Procurement, Paper Usage, and Certification of Sustainable Forest Management by the Federal Government" (better known as the Green Procurement Decree) and the Law on Procurement, Leasing, and Services for the Public Sector.
Based on an analysis of these regulations, it is necessary to adjust them; therefore, a proposal for additions and reforms must be presented that will define what the mechanism will be to ensure traceability of national certified products from harvesting areas to consumers.
This is intended to encourage and promote purchases of certified products that are required by public entities, and includes the responsibilities and obligations of those who are hired for construction services within the Public Administration in order to ensure that the wood used also comes from certified sources.The proposal will be presented to SEMARNAT to form a working group to examine what adjustments are required.The preliminary proposal is set to be ready by the end of 2015.
Likewise, the project will make any necessary adjustments to its planning by seeking to free up resources to hire a specialized consultant who may follow up on this issue from the review of the Decree and Law on Procurement to the drafting of a specific proposal to amend the mentioned legislation and make proposals for procurement protocols at the state level.
- Michoacán Procurement Agreement
The Michoacán Government Procurement Agreement has failed to materialize because the state has had three different governors who all have installed their own working teams upon taking power, which has led to constant changes in the key positions involved in the signing of the Agreement.
-Regarding the goal of procurement contracts/agreements entered into with public institutions, the former partner of the Project, the Rainforest Alliance (RA), was working with the CFE el Balcón, Guerrero to make sales of certified products. However, these developments were not reported because the evidence of such purchases and sales was not available.In November 2014, as part of the proof of the resources entrusted to them, the RA presented 16 invoices for 12 procurement contracts that were signed by agencies of the State Government of Guerrero and by a municipal governmentIn the 2013 PIR, three more formalized agreements had been reported which reaches the goal of 15 certified timber procurement agreements/contracts with public institutions.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Community capacity is strengthened to achieve and maintain certification, and to manage their forests in a sustainable and biodiversity friendly manner

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Increase in number of forest communities receiving support to move towards certification

baseline.comment: Approx. 225 communities in 4 project regions with potential to achieve certification

target.comment: 50 communities receiving assistance from project towards certification

actual.comment:
In this period, technical assistance was provided to 76 CFEs so that they would agree to supports to achieve certification.
26 in the Northern Region: 12 in Chihuahua and 14 in Durango;
25 in the East Central Region: 13 in Puebla, 1 in Veracruz, and 11 pieces of land in Hidalgo.
10 in the Central Region: 2 in Jalisco and 8 in Michoacán;
5 in the Southern Region: 5 CFEs in Oaxaca;
10 in the Southeastern Region: 4 in Campeche and 6 in Quintana Roo.
In the areas with project involvement, 89 pieces of land were aided by the PRONAFOR 2015 to attain certification in the amount of $516,469 USD for a surface of 737,935 ha. Of these, 33 were for CFEs of the Northern Region (11 PTA, 3 NMX; 19 FSC); 24 of the Central Region (12 PTA, 3 NMX; 9 FSC); 31 from the Central East Region (11 PTA, 6 NMX; 14 FSC); and one from the Southern Region (PTA).
Additionally, the CONAFOR provides support resources for certification processes, with 45 CFEs of the project's areas of focus benefiting in 2015 with $368,112 USD; four PTAs of the Northern, East Central, and Southern Regions; 33 for NMX certification of the Northern, Central, and East Central Regions; eight pieces of land with support for FSC international certification the Northern, Central, and Eastern Regions.
Furthermore, with the second and third calls for PRONAFOR 2014, 39 pieces of land were given support for certification under the three standards in the amount of $403,881 USD (20 pieces of land in the Northern Region, six pieces of land in the Central Region, eight in the East Central Region, three in the Southern Region, and two in the Southeastern Region); 37 pieces of land were given support for certification in the amount of $313,312 USD (27 in the Northern Region, and three pieces of land each in the East Central Region and the Southern Region; and one more in the Southeastern Region).
Cumulatively, 400 CFEs have received technical assistance, either directly from project personnel or from consultants hired to provide support to CFEs in our areas of focus.
Results in terms of certificates obtained are described within the following indicator.
On the other hand, in the perception study, the survey respondents were asked whether they believed that government support resources to promote forest certification had increased, remained the same, or decreased in recent years. In response, 67% said that they believe they have increased, 26% believe they have remained the same, and the rest of them believe that they have diminished.
The foregoing tells us that increased priority and resources for forest certification is not just in numbers, but also perceived by producers, TFSPs, and institutional personnel.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2. Forest area conserved through biodiversity-friendly forest management certified following a stepwise approach, including participation in
Preventive technical audits (PTAs) administered by CONAFOR
Mexican national standard for sustainable forest management (NMX) certification
Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certification

baseline.comment:
- 776 ha under PTA audits
- 0 ha under NMX certification
- 708,361 ha under FSC certification

target.comment:
- 500,776 ha under PTAs
- 500,000 ha under NMX
- 1,208,361 ha under FSC

actual.comment:
Progress on the Baseline
Currently, of the 37 baseline CFEs, 29 are certified, 28 are under the FSC scheme, and one is under the NMX sceme, amounting to a cumulative area of 734,896.65 ha.
Of the 29 certified CFEs, five achieved certification in this period. Of the eight remaining baseline CFEs, six have expired certificates and one is in process of recertification.
Progress in Project Areas of Focus (11 States).
in the project's areas of focus, the following results have been achieved in this period:
22 pieces of land under the PTA scheme, with 30,701.21 ha; 3 pieces of land are in the Northern Region with an area of 9,342.49; 12 pieces of land are in the Central Region, with 18282.22 ha; and seven pieces of land are in the East Central Region with an area of 3,046.50 ha;
34 pieces of land with NMX national certification with an additional area of 227,608.86 ha; 22 pieces of land in the Northern Region with an area of 212,571.73; 2 pieces of land in the Central Region with 3648.50 ha; 9 pieces of land in the East Central region with 5890.59 ha; and 1 piece of land in the Southern Region with 5498.04 ha.
16 pieces of land with international FSC certification with an additional certified area of 175,934.45 ha; 6 pieces of land are in the Northern Region with an area of 142,579.77 ha; one piece of land in the Central Region with 5,969 ha; 8 pieces of land in the East Central Region with an area of 5,846.68 ha; and 1 piece of land in the Southeast Region with 21,539 ha.
Cumulatively, in the project's areas of focus, 1.77 million ha have been certified as detailed below:
120 pieces of land under the PTA scheme with an area of 443,353.01, representing 89% of the overall goal of the project for this certification scheme (500,776 ha); 34 pieces of land are in the Northern Region with an area of 356,277.98 ha; 29 pieces of land in the Central Region with 49,956.98 ha; 57 pieces of land in the East Central Region with an area 37,118.05 ha.
77 pieces of land with NMX national certification with an area of 495,361.98 ha, representing 99% of the overall goal of the project for this certification scheme (500,000 ha); 45 pieces of land are in the Northern Region with an area of 422,157.40 ha; six pieces of land in the Central Region with 20543.50 ha; 20 pieces of land of the Central East Region with an area 16,382.70 ha; and six pieces of land in the South Region with an area of 36,278.38 ha.
52 pieces of land with FSC international certification with an area of 839,529.78 ha, representing 69% of the overall project goal for this type of certification (1,208,361 ha); 25 pieces of land are in the Northern Region with an area of 686,253.03 ha; 3 pieces of land in the Central Region with 18624.05 ha; 19 pieces of land in the East Central Region, with an area 24257.87 ha; four pieces of land in the Southern Region, with an area of 74,752.33 ha; and the Southeast Region with two pieces of land with an area of 46,022.50.
There are 29 pieces of land under the PTA scheme and which also have FSC international certification, amounting to a cumulative area of 261,436 ha. Furthermore, 28 pieces of land with PTA also have NMX national certification, with an area of 96,586.63.
There is one piece of land under the NMX national certification scheme and the FSC international certification (Ejido Salto de Camellones, Durango; 11,903.55 ha)
Only two pieces of land in the project's areas of focus are under all three certification schemes (PTA-NMX-FSC) with an area of 4,394 ha (Ejido San Rafael Ixtapalucan, Puebla y El Empedrado, Jalisco).
Progress in Certification at the National Level (32 States)
There are 293 certified pieces of land nationwide that amount to an area of 1.89 million ha (PTA: 517,266 ha; NMX: 518,106 ha; FSC: 856,503 ha) and another 288 pieces of land in process of certification that reach an area of 1.5 million ha. It is important to note that 93% of Mexico's certified area is within the project's areas of focus.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Number of Community Forestry Enterprises (CFEs) in biodiverse areas participating in the project, and trained in BD management to apply safeguard measures in accordance with FSC Principles & Criteria

baseline.comment: 0 CFEs participating in project

target.comment: 40 CFEs trained in BD management

actual.comment:
As a result of the specialized consultancy provided by the project, 114 CFEs have concluded their studies to identify high conservation value areas.
Additionally, nearly 592 pieces of land are on record that incorporate biodiversity criteria into their FMPs based on the Best Biodiversity Conservation Practices Manual that the project produced in 2013, which has had an impact on an area of around 1.2 million ha. Additionally, with the CONAFOR's support, eight consultancies are in process of being hired to advise producers on incorporating biodiversity criteria into their FMPs on 720 pieces of land in the states of Chihuahua, Durango, Jalisco, Michoacán, Puebla Oaxaca, Guerrero, Campeche, and Quintana Roo, which amount to 1.1 million ha.
The project designed a base structure to prepare Regional Biodiversity Studies (RESs) Currently, there are 12 RESs in Chihuahua and Durango in their final stage of preparation. They consider site-level, forest-stand-level, and landscape-level biodiversity conservation practices on an area of 8 million ha.
Likewise, 131 Community Forest Enterprises (CFEs) were trained to prepare their Biological Monitoring and Habitat Quality Programs; these tools allow them to obtain or maintain certification and provide information on the impact of productive activity on a piece of land's biodiversity. Of these CFEs, 71 have already prepared their monitoring programs, 14 of which are implementing on-site activities. Five courses that will train 46 more CFEs are planned for the second half of 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Economic incentives are in place to attract and keep Community Forestry Enterprises committed to sustainable forestry and biodiversity management practices

actual.comment:
In June 2015, the third remeasurement (and the second one taking the adjustment of the 2013 baseline into consideration) of production costs per board foot (in USD) of the 2014-2015 cycle took place. The results are as follows:
CFE Juanacatlán, Jal.: $0.35 USD

CFE Petcacab, Q. Roo: $1.50 USD
At the regional level, by converting 2012 values (which are those of the project baseline) to current ones, the average by region of focus is as follows:
Northern Region: $0.29 USD, which represents 21% lower production costs with respect to the baseline.
Central Region: $0.41 USD, which represents 37% lower production costs with respect to the baseline.
Southern Region: $0.54 USD, which represents 4% lower production costs with respect to the baseline.
Southeastern Region: $1.43 USD, Which represents a 123% increase with respect to the baseline. The foregoing is due to the fact that raw material costs were not considered in production costs calculated on the baseline.
According to the remeasurement of the indicators of these nine CFEs, there has been an overall decrease in production costs in all regions, with an average recorded decrease of 15%, which represents progress of 50% more than the goal set for this indicator (-10%).
As mentioned in the first section of this report, the sample of monitored CFEs has increased, which has a universe of 32 (those that process sawn timber) in the case of costs.
Average production costs by region are shown below (per board foot):
Northern Region (7 CFEs): $0.41 USD
Central Region (7 CFEs): $0.45 USD
East Central Region (8 CFEs): $0.59 USD
Southern Region (7 CFEs): $0.58 USD
Southeastern Region (3 CFEs): 1.23 USD
The average production costs of the 32 CFEs are 0.63 USD per board foot
Furthermore, the sawmill coefficients of the nine CFEs were remeasured, resulting in the following values:
CFE Juanacatlán, Jal.: 44.80%
CFE San Pedro Jacuaro, Mich.: 56%
CFE San Rafael Ixtapaluca, Pue.: 55.0%

The average sawmill coefficient by region is as follows:

Central Region: 52% on average, which represents a 21% increase in sawmill coefficient with respect to the baseline.
Southern Region: 49% on average, which represents a 17% decrease in sawmill coefficient with respect to the baseline.
Southeastern Region: 51% on average, which represents a 0.2% decrease in sawmill coefficient with respect to the baseline.
According to the monitoring of the nine mentioned CFEs, the results for sawmill coefficient are satisfactory overall with a 17% increase with respect to the baseline, representing more than three times the established goal of 5%.
Sawmill coefficients were also monitored in 34 CFEs in all Regions. Below are the average sawmill coefficients by region:

After these two competitiveness indicators (costs and sawmill coefficient) were reviewed and showed satisfactory results, it is important to note that the CFE of Ejido Yoquivo, Chihuahua, the project's flagship CFE for the state, obtained the National Forestry Merit Award in the industry category.
The indicator of investment in biodiversity was reported in the first section

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2. Increase in demand for certified wood products, measured via
% of certified CFE sales to certified buyers
Number of chain-of-custody certifications among private sector wood processors and manufacturers
Number of alliances resulting in sales contracts formed between CFEs and international or national buyers specifically demanding certified forest products

baseline.comment:
- 32% of certified sales to certified buyers
- 22 chain of custody certification
- 0 new alliances facilitated by project

target.comment:
- 50% of certified CFE sales to certified buyers
- 42 chain of custody certifications
- 20 alliances

actual.comment:
a)Of the 37 CFEs that make up the baseline, 29 have a valid forestry certificate.17 of these 29 CFEs sell certified timber to Chain of Custody-certified purchasers.The average percentage of certified timber sold by these 17 CFEs to CoC-certified companies is 53.2%, which shows an increase with respect to the 32% reported as a baseline in 2009.
Furthermore, eight other certified CFEs in addition to the baseline are recorded. They sell 60% of their products on average to CoC-certified purchasers.
In total, there are 25 certified CFEs on record in the project's areas of focus that sell 55.44% of their products on average to CoC purchasers. Although the percentage of sales to CoC-certified purchasers is similar to that of the previous period, the number of CFEs did increase from 14 to 25, which speaks to a greater volume of certified timber from legal sources reaching the end consumer.
b)Overall, chain of custody (CoC) certification is one of the goals with the greatest progress in this period. Until November 2014, the project had failed to obtain a single CoC certification. However, from December 2014 to June 2015, 10 CoC certifications have been finalized. This was because a maturing process was necessary for the CFEs, starting with the certification of their pieces of land and everything which that entails in order to certify their industry.
With these 10 CoC certifications and the 22 baseline ones, there is cumulative progress of 76% (32 CoC certifications). Additionally, there are another 12 enterprises in process of CoC certification in the East Central Region, which the project supported by hiring four consultants who are providing specialized consultancy to integrate their Documented Control Systems.
There are 193 companies nationwide with valid certificates, among which include printing houses, publishers, cardboard and paper factories, and forestry companies.
c)In the Northern Region during this period, another new partnership between forest ejidos for commercial purposes was incorporated as a result of the actions and specialized assistance of project personnel. This Partnership is called Productos Silvícolas El Vergel, ARIC, which consists of six Ejidos, one Community, and one Small Property which belong to the municipality of Balleza,
Additionally, in the Northern Region, there are two new partnerships of ejidos in process in Chihuahua that will be legally incorporated before a notary public in the third quarter of 2015. These are: (1) Asociatividad Región de Basaseachi, and (2) Silvicultores de la Región de Madera.
In the Southeastern Region, in collaboration with the CONABIO, two groups of producers have received consultancy since 2014 in order to become part of a partnership model to process and market their products. Finally, the alliance called “Carbón Vegetal y Biodiversidad de Calakmul” ["Charcoal and Biodiversity in Calakmul"] was successfully established. It is made up of two ejidos: Álvaro Obregón y Nuevo Becal, Campeche; “Alianza Selva Maya de Quintana Roo UE” ["Mayan Jungle Alliance of Quintana Roo UE"] was also established and is made up of 5 ejidos: Bacalar, Felipe Carrillo Puerto, NohBec, Petcacab y Polinkín, Xhazil, and Annexes of the municipality of Felipe Carrillo Puerto, Quintana Roo.
For the past PIR, the following three partnerships formed through intervention were reportedIn conclusion, there have been four project-based partnerships (assembled from inception to their formal establishment by the project) and two others formed through project collaboration with other partners. In total, six partnerships have been formed, accounting for 30% of the progress toward the overall goal.
It is noteworthy that, although progress is behind schedule, the project has promoted solid and functional partnership models that go beyond bringing ejidos together simply to market sawn timber.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Area receiving payments for Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD) on the voluntary market, providing additional income streams to CFEs to improve returns of certified forestry

baseline.comment: 0 ha receiving payments under REDD scheme

target.comment: 100,000 ha receiving REDD payments

actual.comment: To date, the REDD+ payments have not been made; therefore, there is no progress to report. However, as regards the REDD+ agenda, the project has participated by sharing the Gender Equality Strategy with the CONAFOR and the SEMARNAT to prepare the Special Climate Change Program (PECC, per its Spanish initials); it was also shared with MREDD+ Alliance and was considered to create two documents, which are: "Gender Legal Analysis and REDD+" and "Gender Action Plan and REDD+."

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Increase in investment in CFEs to improve management and business practices that contribute to BD objectives, through various mechanisms

baseline.comment:
to be established
11 certified CFEs accessing credit

target.comment:
USD 15 million invested in CFEs facilitated by project
21 certified CFEs accessing credit

actual.comment:
For the 2015 PRONAFOR call, with project support, 68 CFEs have resources from this program to use during this fiscal year in the amount of $4,069,610 USD with resources from the Forest Development Office and $2,898,740 USD from the Production Chain Incorporation Office, for a total of $6,968,350.
With the foregoing, in the lifespan of the project so far, the CONAFOR has invested $22,261,752 USD into subsidies for CFEs in the project's areas of focus, representing 48% more that what was planned for the end of the project ($15,000,000).
The main support resorces granted by the CONAFOR to the CFEs that are of interest to the project were as follows:
In the Northern Region, as a result of the work to establish the partnership "Productos Silvícolas del Vergel ARIC" in Chihuahua, the request was supported for the investment for a sawmill in the amount of $323,597 USD.
In the Central Region, support was provided to update the business plan of the CFE Ejido San Pedro Jacauro, Michoacán, which served to give them access to support in order to modernize their sawmill for $349,406 USD.
In the East Central Region, with respect to production chain support resources promoted by the Project, we have granted two of them to modernize the forest industry: Ejido La Selva, Veracruz ($324,760 USD) and Ejido Piedra Ancha Segunda Ampliación, Puebla ($295,327 USD). Likewise, there are support resources for $62,893 USD for the 12 CoC certificates in process.
In the Southeast Region, the Ejido NohBec received support resources from the PRONAFOR for forest roads and forest cultivation in the amount of $83,051 USD.
Credits
As a result of the technical assistance and specialized advising provided by the project, two credits were finalized during this period in the following CFEs:
San Pedro el Alto, Zimatlán, Oaxaca (Southern Region): A credit was finalized with Nacional Financiera de Desarrollo in order to modernize its sawmill in the amount of $377,358 USD.
Ejido Nuevo Becal, Campeche (Southeastern Region); a group of ejidatarios (not the whole ejido) called Compañeros en Vuelo SPR de RL accessed a credit with Agrofinanciera DG in the amount of $29,489 USD. The resources were invested for the ejido's overall operations.
Furthermore, in the Northern Region, two lines of credit are in process of approval; one of them is for the enterprise Productos Forestales La Ciudad (Durango) in the amount of $350 mil USD for working capital, managed through SOFOM E.N.R. of the enterprise New Holland, CNH Servicios Comerciales S.A. de C.V., and the other line of credit will be managed by Ejido La Pinta, La Joya, and Annexes of the municipality of Balleza, Chihuahua in the amount of $43 mil USD for working capital with BANORTE.
In the Southern Region, a credit with Santa Catarina Ixtepeji to purchase a drying stove is being promoted, but it has not been successfully finalized because of the imminent change of ejido commissioner.
In the Central Region, a credit with the Ejido el Empedrado, Jalisco for working capital is being promotedd. The most appropriate scheme for the ejido is being evaluated. However, the financial entity with the greatest financing possibility would be FINDECA.
In the Southeastern Region, in collaboration with FIRA, a credit with the Empresa Social Forestal del Ejido Tres Garantías in Quintana Roo has been promoted, and it is currently in process of approval.
During the project's span so far, five credits have been finalized, which are the two mentioned previously and those three finalized during earlier periods (Ejido Vencedores, Durango; Ejido Yoquivo, Chihuahua; and Ejido Veinte de Noviembre, Campeche).
With the mentioned progress and the baseline of 11 credits, there is cumulative progress of 16 credits, signifying 76% of the total project goal (21 credits). It is anticipated that this goal will be met at the end of the project.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback, and evaluation systems are in place for quantitative and qualitative assessment of project impacts

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Rate of deforestation and degradation in project impact study sites

baseline.comment:
The baseline (expressed by type of use and average basal area */ha) is:
1. Non-certified and utilization hiatus: 23.12 m2/ha
2. Non-certified and in utilization: 22.89 m2/has
3. Non-certified and protected natural area: 22.49 m2/ha
4. Non-certified and without utilization permit: 18.53 m2/ha
5. Certified and in utilization hiatus: 20.23 m2/ha
6. Certified and with utilization permit: 20.83 m2/ha
7. Certified and in protected natural area: 54.78 m2/ha

target.comment: 0% deforestation in certified sites; <10% of plots with reduced basal area in certified sites

actual.comment:
In 2015, "Remeasurement of Permanent Sites to Assess Changes in Deforestation, Forest Degradation, and Biodiversity in the State of Durango" was produced. To do so, data from 155 permanent monitoring sites were used (108 site remeasured in 2013, and 47 in 2014).
This task only took into account five management regimes in relation to the seven considered in the period period because of the temporary nature of the remeasurement of sites. These were:
1. Uncertified and utilization in suspension
2. Uncertified and with utilization permit
3. Certified and utilization in suspension
4. Certified and with utilization permit
5. Certified and on Natural Protected Areas
The foregoing enabled a comparative analysis related to monitoring 395 sites used in the previous study. Regarding the number of trees (N) and the base area (G), which are variables that can be used to look for signs of forest degradation and deforestation, the study resulted in the following rates of change in estimated mean values for these verifiers (a positive value signifies an increase, while a negative value represents a decrease):
-Uncertified and utilization in suspension: rate of change for N: 65.12%; rate of change for G: 67.46%
Uncertified and with utilization permit: rate of change for N:-6.32%; rate of change for G: 4.79%
-Certified and utilization in suspension: rate of change for N: -6.86%; rate of change for G: 4.79%
-Certified and with utilization permit: rate of change for N: 3.02%; rate of change for G: 11.05%
-Certified and on Natural Protected Area: rate of change for N: 3.51%; rate of change for G: 10.54%
It is observed that management regimes 1, 4, and 5 record positive rates of change, which indicates increased cover and increased volumes from monitored sites. In the regime of "certified and utilization in suspension," negative rates are observed, which is interpreted as a sign of deforestation and forest degradation. As important finding a significant increase in basal area in the regime if “certificate and whit utilization permit “ was observed during this first period of observation, this result is interesting because it can be considered an indicator showing that promotes responsible forest management increased forest cover.
On the other hand, in the East Central Region, the Guide to establish Permanent Assessment Sites for Plant Diversity is under development. It will be used to assess impacts from silvicultural treatments on pieces of land under management.
Through this assessment, the rates of deforestation and forest degradation in areas monitored can be defined based on basal area and woodland density indicators; along with these indicators, diversity will be measured in the shrub and herb layers, thereby obtaining data for the species richness of a community, changes in species composition, and species richness between communities.
In the PIR period, the establishment of 160 of these sites in the region of the Sierra Norte de Puebla (where the greatest number of certified pieces of land exists in the region) was financed on four pieces of land with a valid utilization permit that are in operation and have a good management certificate; based on these measurements, the baseline of the already stated basal area and density per species was defined.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Rate of change in forest floral diversity (proxy for overall BD) in project impact study sites

baseline.comment:
The following baseline was established (expressed by average richness of tree species and type of management):
1.- Non-certified and in utilization hiatus: 8 species
2.-Non-certified and in utilization: 7 species
3.- Non-certified and protected natural area: 6 species.
4.- Non-certified and without utilization permit: 7 species.
5.- Certified and in utilization hiatus: 7 species.
6.- Non-certified and in utilization: 7 species.
7.- Certified and protected natural area: 9 species.

target.comment: <10% of plots with declining forest floral diversity in certified sites

actual.comment:
"Remeasurement of Permanent Sites to Assess Changes in Deforestation, Forest Degradation, and Biodiversity in Forests of the State of Durango" also collected information on average tree species richness. This work only considered five management regimes in relation to the seven considered in the previous period. These regimes and the number of species for each one of them, as well as the years of study, are listed below (155 were considered during period 1 (2008-2009) and 155 were considered during period 2 (2013-2014)):
1. Uncertified and utilization in suspension: 7 species; two species decreased with respect to the previous period.
2. Uncertified and with utilization permit: 8 species; remained the same with respect to the previous period.
3. Certified and utilization in suspension: 7 species; remained the same with respect to the previous period.
4. Certified and with utilization permit: 8 species; remained the same with respect to the previous period.
5. Certified and on Natural Protected Areas: 9 species; remained the same with respect to the previous period.
The results of the study still do not produce enough tested evidence to conclude that there is a decrease in negative impacts in certified forests in terms of deforestation, forest degradation, and loss of biodiversity in the area of study. However, the majority of the verifiers collected during the study display values or units of measurement that suggest that the certified forest regime exhibits better attributes for biodiversity conservation compared to the regime of uncertified management without utilization, which was the only regime that exhibited decreases.
Note: The results presented above are from a comparison of 155 sites samples in the 2008-2009 period and 150 sites in the 2013-2014 period, which therefore must be supplemented with remeasurement at other sites in order to more accurately assess spatial and temporal changes of the variables of Deforestation, Forest Degradation, and Biodiversity. During the next two years, the remaining sites will be remeasured, which will allow for a better assessment of the baseline change dynamic defined in the previous study (395). Based on the foregoing, in relation to the baseline, they might not match.

CFE Ãlvaro ObregÃ³n $1,040,000.00

target.comment: 30% ave increase in CFE gross revenues

actual.comment:
In June 2015, the third remeasurement of annual revenue (in USD) by CFEs determined through intensive monitoring of was made (the second after the baseline adjustment in the 2012-2013 period), resulting in the following values;
CFE Juanacatlán, Jal.: $250,508 USD
CFE San Pedro Jacuaro, Mich.: $592,126 USD
CFE San Rafael Ixtapaluca, Pue.: $90,146 USD
CFE Santo Domingo Coatlán, Oax.: $677,336 USD
CFE Bajos del Balsamar, Gro.: $139,567 USD
CFE San Pablo, Dgo.: $3,583,573 USD
CFE Ejido Yoquivo, Chi.: $1,891,202 USD
CFE Ejido Álvaro Obregón, Campeche: $25,157 USD
CFE Petcacab, Q. Roo.: $560,783 USD
At the regional level, by converting 2012 values (which are those of the project baseline) to current ones, the averages are as follows:
Central Region: $289,861 USD, Which represents 97% greater annual revenue with respect to the baseline.
Southern Region: $380,779 USD. 38% less annual revenue with respect to the baseline due to a decreased utilization volume authorized by the SEMARNAT for the ejido of Bajos de Balsamar
Northern Region: $2’551,927 USD, 38% more annual revenue with respect to the baseline.
Southeast Region: 273,121, 65% less with respect to the baseline, which is due to the persistence of the low sawmill operation in Álvaro Obregón and they are only dedicated to the contract manufacturing of round wood in small volumes.
According to the foregoing, there has been an average revenue increase of 18% with respect to the baseline. It is worth mentioning that results in this period are minimized when converted to US dollars because of the downward fluctuation of the peso, as well as to reiterate that revenues are largely determined by volumes authorized by the SEMARNAT.
On the other hand, the Mid-Term Review and the Project Board determined that monitoring only one CFE per state does not allow for the objective observation of project impact on competitiveness indicators of CFEs.
In this regard, in June 2015, the revenues of 35 CFEs in the project's areas of focus were monitored. Average revenues by region are shown below:
Northern Region (7 CFEs): $3,944,411 USD
Central Region (7 CFEs): $417,204 USD
East Central Region (7 CFEs): $236,914 USD
Southern Region (8 CFEs): $434,787 USD
Southeastern Region (6 CFEs): 283,371 USD
The average revenue for the 35 monitored CFEs is $1,067,663 USD per year.
In 2016, the revenue of these same enterprises will be monitored again to find out the change with respect to the current period.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Level of participation of women and men in operations of CFEs in project impact study sites

baseline.comment: 1% of women working for CFE operatios

target.comment: 50% ave. increase participation of women in CFE operations

actual.comment:
Of the nine CFEs monitored for competitiveness indicators, a baseline for women working for these enterprises was also prepared.
In this regard, in 2012, of the 308 workers in these nine CFEs, three were women, that is, only 1%. That year, only three of the nine enterprises had women in their workforce. The average number of women per CFE was 0.6 in 2012.
In June 2015, there are 18 women working within the operations of the nine CFEs, representing 4% of total workers. Seven of the nine CFEs now have at least one women in their workforces. In 2015, the average number of women in these nine CFEs is two.
To have a more objective overview of the level of participation of women in CFE operations, gender information was collected in June 2015 from a sample of 36 CFEs receiving project support. This will allow us to have a more meaningful baseline that will serve to compare it to the results obtained in 2016.
Below are the numbers by region taken from monitoring 36 CFEs:
Northern Region: 137 women working in seven CFEs; 19 women per EFC on average.
East Central Region: Five women working in eight CFEs; less than one woman per EFC on average.
Central Region: Six women working in seven CFEs; less than one woman per EFC on average.
Southern Region: 22 women working in eight CFEs; about three women per EFC on average.
Southeastern Region: 19 women working in six CFEs; three women per EFC on average.
There are 189 women recorded as working in the 36 CFEs of all the regions nationwide. This means five women on average per each CFE. 24 of the 36 CFEs have at least one woman working in their workforces (66%).
The percentage of women working in relation to the total number of workers of these 36 CFEs is 9%.
Furthermore, as mentioned in the section on training, 491 women attended courses/workshops organized by the project in this period, which means that they represent 16% of attendees. Of the women who were trained, 25% developed their certification capacities, 17% were trained in biodiversity, 16% in competitiveness and markets, 11% in biological monitoring, 11% in Forest Management, and 1% in HCV.
With respect to where the trained women come from, 31% are from CFEs, 24% are Technical Forestry Service Providers, 19% are from academia, 12% are from the CONAFOR, 7% are from NGOs, 4% are from the SEMARNAT, 2% are from State Governments, 1% are from the PROFEPA, 0.4% are from the CONANP, and 0.4% are from the CONABIO.
Additionally, as reported in the previous report, the project has provided special consultancy and undertaken actions to include a gender perspective in regulatory and planning instruments that have undergone updating/drafting processes.
Finally, in the perception study conducted by the project, some test items to monitor the perception of women's participation in forestry activity were included.
Regarding the question, "During the last five years of women's participation in forestry activities on forest lands and in the forestry enterprise (sawmill), has it decreased, remained the same, or increased? Of those surveyed, 52% believed that it had remained the same, 41% believed that it has increased, and 7% believed that it has decreased.
Regarding the question, "During the next five years of women's participation in forestry activities on forest lands and in the forestry enterprise (sawmill), will it decrease, remain the same, or increase?" Of those surveyed, 69% believe that it will remain the same, 26% believe that it will increase, and 5% believe that it will decrease.
The people's perspective is that women's participation in decision-making as in forestry activity will be greater in the following years.

iati-activity.title: Fort. preparación REDD+ en México y Coop. Sur-Sur
